child.pub-comments: "For many of these languages ther are several named dialects, which have sometimes been cited in the literature as separate languages, but with no name for the language or group as a whole. Also, many of these groups have been cited according to geographical locations, clan names or names used by other groups, as well as by their own name" (Bradley 2007: 178).

child.geography: Inland in southern Vietnam south of the Austronesian Chamic groups Rhade and Jarai

child.pub-comments: These languages are "quite diverse and mostly poorly described" (Bradley 2007: 177).
"East Katuic comprises many more named groups, but many of them seem to be mutually intelligible dialects" (Bradley 2007: 177).
Bradley does not specifiy Eastern or Western Katu, so I have included the codes for both.

child.pub-comments: Our database contains codes for both Upper and Lower Ta-oih, but Bradley doesn't specify which language he is refering to here. Since Lower Ta-oih does not list simply Ta-oih as an alternate name, I've chosen to use the code for Upper Ta-oih for this node.

child.geography: Further north [than the other Northern Mon-Khmer groups]; mainly west of the Salween
In one village near Inle Lake in Burma
child.publications: Bradley, David. 2007. East and Southeast Asia. In Christopher Moseley, Encyclopedia of the World's Endangered Languages, 1 edn. Abingdon: Routledge. ISBN 070071197X

child.pub-comments: "[S]ome scholars prefer to classify Phuman as an Angkuic language" (Bradley 2007: 176).
child.geography: In Shuangjiang and surrounding counties in China; widely scattered further south
child.publications: Bradley, David. 2007. East and Southeast Asia. In Christopher Moseley, Encyclopedia of the World's Endangered Languages, 1 edn. Abingdon: Routledge. ISBN 070071197X

child.geography: Around Nam Hsan in northern Shan State, Burma, in China, and more recently in Thailand

child.publications: Bradley, David. 2007. East and Southeast Asia. In Christopher Moseley, Encyclopedia of the World's Endangered Languages, 1 edn. Abingdon: Routledge. ISBN 070071197X

child.pub-comments: Silver Palaung is listed as an alternate name for Pale in the database.

child.pub-comments: Bradley doesn't classify this language himself, but mentions it in the sections titled "Northern Mon-Khmer" in association with the Palaungic languages. He writes that "Mitani (1978) evaluates old sources to suggest that Palaung or Ta-ang… is somewhat different from Rumai" (2007: 176).

child.pub-comments: Bradley considers these three languages part of a subgroup but does not give a name for it.

child.geography: Northern Laos, Vietnam, Thailand, China, Burma; also spoken by some refugees in western countries
child.publications: Bradley, David. 2007. East and Southeast Asia. In Christopher Moseley, Encyclopedia of the World's Endangered Languages, 1 edn. Abingdon: Routledge. ISBN 070071197X

child.pub-comments: This subgroup is "one language with minor dialect differences but without a group name; speakers of this language call themselves Mal, Pray or Phay according to dialect. Thai authorities usually call this group T'in… but locally this name is not used" (Bradley 2007: 176).
child.geography: Thailand and adjacent areas of Laos
child.publications: Bradley, David. 2007. East and Southeast Asia. In Christopher Moseley, Encyclopedia of the World's Endangered Languages, 1 edn. Abingdon: Routledge. ISBN 070071197X

child.pub-comments: The author notes that "some older literature also cites another group, Yumbri, but this is the same [as Malbri]" (Bradley 2007: 176).

child.pub-comments: Bradley only mentions the name of one language explicitly, while he calls the others dialects, dialect groups or subdialects. He refers to the Nicobarese languages minus Shom Peng as a "dialect chain" (2007: 178), so I have chosen this name for the parent language of the Nicobarese dialect groups.

child.pub-comments: Bradley calls this a cluster (2007: 176) but it is unclear if he means a dialect group or a subgroup. He also groups Kri and Pong with Maleng, but does not give this group a name.

child.pub-comments: Bradley calls this a cluster (2007: 176) but it is unclear if he means a dialect group or a subgroup. He notes that "[i]n Vietname, these groups are collectively known by the Vietnamese exonym Chut" (2007: 176).
